bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to M.B. Crowell, June 10, 1923

div1.p: [Carter] discusses Crowell's desire that he write regular briefs on the progress against yellow fever. Carter offers his opinion on recent papers on yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to M.B. Crowell, June 10, 1923
div1.opener:
Miscel-
Nelson. L. Leaf
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
June 10, 1923.
Dr. M. B. Crowell, Office Editor,
Thomas Nelson and Sons,
381 Fourth Avenue,
New York, N. Y.
Dear Doctor Crowell:
div1.p:
I think I understand what you wish: That I, at each period of
six months give a brief summary of progress of knowledge of yellow
fever, after which would come the bibliography as abstracted by your
office, my part to have no connection with--or, indeed, special al-
lusion to--the articles abstracted. Is this correct, or would you
wish allusion to the articles abstracted when they contained (a) new
points of some value, as is possibly the case in the one by Perrin:
or (b) are almost entirely erroneous and valueless as that by Anig-
stein?

It is fair to say that only about one in ten of the articles
written on yellow fever contain anything new of value and if the
first method (a) be followed. you will not have to clutter up your
publication with reviews of them.

In regard to your question as to whether I wish fuller abstracts
of the articles sent, I would say that this is unnecessary as I have
seen them all, except the one ascribed to me from the Cronica Medical
of Lima. I think this is a reprint, or maybe an abstract, of an ar-
ticle from the American Journal of Tropical Medecine, which you have
already reviewed. There seems no use to do so a second time.

I would suggest, however, that you add to the articles abstract-
ed the following papers:
Connor, M. E.: Final Report on the Control of Yellow Fever in
Merida, Yucatan, Mexico. American Journal of Tropical Medecine, Nov./22.
Connor, M. E.: Notes on Yellow Fever in Mexico. Same journal,
March/23.
Gouzien, Medecin Inspecteur Général, etc. La Fièvre Jaune en
Afrique Occidentale, en 1922. Office Inter-
national d'Hygiene Publique, Dec./22.

This last is easily the most important publication that has ap-
peared during this year.

Please note the question in the first part of this letter, so
that I may know exactly what you wish me to do.
